title: Returning values from a closure
question: This code is valid Swift – true or false?
hint: Make sure the value that is returned matches what is expected.

correct.answer:
let measureSize = { (inches: Int) -> String in
	switch inches {
	case 0...26:
		return "XS"
	case 27...30:
		return "S"
	case 31...34:
		return "M"
	case 35...38:
		return "L"
	default:
		return "XL"
	}
}
measureSize(36)

let bakeBirthdayCake = { (name: String) -> Int in
	print("I've made a cake for \(name); here's the bill.")
	return 50
}

wrong.reason: This doesn't tell Swift what data type depth will be.
This doesn't tell Swift what data type will be returned.

wrong.answer:
let convertNumerals = { (numeral: String) -> String in
	switch numeral {
	case "I":
		return "1"
	case "II":
		return "2"
	case "III":
		return "3"
	}
}
print(convertNumerals("II"))
wrong.reason: The switch statement does not cover all possible cases.
This uses invalid syntax – to create a closure this should use let callNumber or var callNumber.

wrong.answer:
var buyMagazine = { (name: String) -> Int in
	let amount = 10
	print("\(name) costs \(amount)")
	return amount
}
buyMagazine(name: "Wired")
wrong.reason: We don't use parameter names when calling a closure.
This attempts to create a range from 1 through to a string, which is not valid.
